rev.comment: /* Countries affected */ moving it to another article
rev.diff:
Line 13: Line 13:
In Tunisia these protests are called the '''Sidi Bouzid Revolt''', derived from [[Sidi Bouzid]], the city where the initial protests began.<ref name="SidiBouzid_FB">{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/video/video.php?v=151395198244689 |title=Niet compatibele browser |publisher=Facebook |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref name="SidiBouzid_libcom">{{cite web|url=http://libcom.org/forums/news/protests-spread-tunisia-29122010 |title=The Sidi Bouzid Revolution: Ben Ali flees as protests spread in Tunisia |publisher=libcom.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref name="SidiBouzid_YT">{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8thJM2nmd_g&feature=related |title=Revolte Tunisie Sidi bouzid 3 |publisher=YouTube |date=2011-01-04 |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> The events have been dubbed in the media as the '''Jasmine Revolution'''<ref name="europe1.fr">{{cite web|author=Par FrÃ©dÃ©ric Frangeul |url=http://www.europe1.fr/International/D-ou-vient-la-revolution-du-jasmin-375743/ |title=DâoÃ¹ vient la "rÃ©volution du jasmin" ? |publisher=Europe1.fr |date=2011-01-19 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref><ref name="translate.google.com">[http://www.europe1.fr/International/D-ou-vient-la-revolution-du-jasmin-375743/ DâoÃ¹ vient la "rÃ©volution du jasmin" ?] Europe1.fr International, 17 january 2011 ([http://translate.google.com/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.europe1.fr%2FInternational%2FD-ou-vient-la-revolution-du-jasmin-375743%2F Google Translate version])</ref> in keeping with the geopolitical nomenclature of "[[color revolutions]]", although the comparison is disputed, notably by many Tunisians themselves.<ref name="translate.google.com">{{cite web|url=http://translate.google.fr/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=fr&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=fr&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.lemonde.fr%2Fafrique%2Farticle%2F2011%2F01%2F17%2Frevolution-du-jasmin-une-expression-qui-ne-fait-pas-l-unanimite_1466871_3212.html |title=Google Translate |language={{fr icon}} |publisher=Translate.google.fr |date=2011-01-17 |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref name="translate.google.com">{{cite web|url=http://translate.google.fr/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=fr&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=fr&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mediapart.fr%2Fclub%2Fblog%2Folivier-malaponti%2F150111%2Frevolution-de-jasmin-0 |title=Google Translate |language={{fr icon}} |publisher=Translate.google.fr |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref name="Le Monde">{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2011/01/17/revolution-du-jasmin-une-expression-qui-ne-fait-pas-l-unanimite_1466871_3212.html/ |title="RÃ©volution du jasmin" : une expression qui ne fait pas l'unanimitÃ© |publisher=LeMonde.fr |date=2011-01-17 |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref><ref name="Mediapart">{{cite web|author=Olivier Malaponti |url=http://www.mediapart.fr/club/blog/olivier-malaponti/150111/revolution-de-jasmin-0 |title=RÃ©volution de jasmin ? |publisher=Mediapart.fr |date=2011-01-15 |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref>
In Tunisia these protests are called the '''Sidi Bouzid Revolt''', derived from [[Sidi Bouzid]], the city where the initial protests began.<ref name="SidiBouzid_FB">{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/video/video.php?v=151395198244689 |title=Niet compatibele browser |publisher=Facebook |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref name="SidiBouzid_libcom">{{cite web|url=http://libcom.org/forums/news/protests-spread-tunisia-29122010 |title=The Sidi Bouzid Revolution: Ben Ali flees as protests spread in Tunisia |publisher=libcom.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref name="SidiBouzid_YT">{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8thJM2nmd_g&feature=related |title=Revolte Tunisie Sidi bouzid 3 |publisher=YouTube |date=2011-01-04 |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> The events have been dubbed in the media as the '''Jasmine Revolution'''<ref name="europe1.fr">{{cite web|author=Par FrÃ©dÃ©ric Frangeul |url=http://www.europe1.fr/International/D-ou-vient-la-revolution-du-jasmin-375743/ |title=DâoÃ¹ vient la "rÃ©volution du jasmin" ? |publisher=Europe1.fr |date=2011-01-19 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref><ref name="translate.google.com">[http://www.europe1.fr/International/D-ou-vient-la-revolution-du-jasmin-375743/ DâoÃ¹ vient la "rÃ©volution du jasmin" ?] Europe1.fr International, 17 january 2011 ([http://translate.google.com/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.europe1.fr%2FInternational%2FD-ou-vient-la-revolution-du-jasmin-375743%2F Google Translate version])</ref> in keeping with the geopolitical nomenclature of "[[color revolutions]]", although the comparison is disputed, notably by many Tunisians themselves.<ref name="translate.google.com">{{cite web|url=http://translate.google.fr/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=fr&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=fr&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.lemonde.fr%2Fafrique%2Farticle%2F2011%2F01%2F17%2Frevolution-du-jasmin-une-expression-qui-ne-fait-pas-l-unanimite_1466871_3212.html |title=Google Translate |language={{fr icon}} |publisher=Translate.google.fr |date=2011-01-17 |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref name="translate.google.com">{{cite web|url=http://translate.google.fr/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=fr&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=fr&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mediapart.fr%2Fclub%2Fblog%2Folivier-malaponti%2F150111%2Frevolution-de-jasmin-0 |title=Google Translate |language={{fr icon}} |publisher=Translate.google.fr |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref name="Le Monde">{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2011/01/17/revolution-du-jasmin-une-expression-qui-ne-fait-pas-l-unanimite_1466871_3212.html/ |title="RÃ©volution du jasmin" : une expression qui ne fait pas l'unanimitÃ© |publisher=LeMonde.fr |date=2011-01-17 |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref><ref name="Mediapart">{{cite web|author=Olivier Malaponti |url=http://www.mediapart.fr/club/blog/olivier-malaponti/150111/revolution-de-jasmin-0 |title=RÃ©volution de jasmin ? |publisher=Mediapart.fr |date=2011-01-15 |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref>
â   â
==Countries affected==
  â
Similar protests actually took place in almost all Arab countries<ref>http://tribune.com.pk/story/121796/the-potato-revolution/</ref> from [[Morocco]] to [[Iraq]], as well as in other states, ranging from [[Gabon]] to [[Albania]], [[Iran]] and [[Kazakhstan]], to [[China]]. China has censored most media coverage of the Arab worldâs popular revolt of the last few weeks<ref>http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jasmine-revolution-coverage-censored-china-159665</ref> leading to difficulty in organizing Jasmine protests in China.<ref>http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/02/20/china.protests/</ref>
  â   â
===China ===
  â
[[China's Jasmine revolution]]<ref>http://www.catholic.org/international/international_story.php?id=40437</ref> have also bought the Chinese government into action. Chinese security officials questioned or detained<ref>http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/20/chinese-officials-detain-activists-protests</ref> scores of activists and warned others against staging protests after an online call was made for demonstrations in 13 cities<ref>http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/20/unrest-morocco-iran-algeria-yemen-china</ref>.
  â
[[File:Voa beijing 230 20feb11.jpg|thumb|The largely silent crowd gathered in front of a [[McDonalds]] restaurant near [[Tiananmen Square]] in [[Beijing]].]]
  â
[[PRC Government]] officials arrested activists, added to the normal police presence, disabled some [[Mobile phone industry in China|cell phone]] [[text messaging]] services and [[Internet censorship in the People's Republic of China|deleted Internet postings]] about protests planned for 14:00 on 20 February in [[Beijing]], [[Shanghai]] and 11 other cities.<ref name="China tries to stamp out">{{cite news| url= http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2011-02-20-china-jasmine-revolution_N.htm| title= China tries to stamp out 'Jasmine Revolution'| publisher= [[usatoday.com]]| date= 20 Feb 2011| accessdate= }}</ref> On the day of the protests, the police turned out en masse to all of the potential protest locations.<ref name="NYChina">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/21/world/asia/21china.html|title=Chinese Security Officials Respond to Call for Protests|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|author=Jacob, Andrew|date=2011-02-20|accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref> Small crowds, including quite a few curious onlookers, gathered at the planned site in [[Beijing]] and [[Shanghai]] but did not chant slogans or hold signs.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/8336611/China-snuffs-out-democracy-protests.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first1=Peter | last1=Foster | first2=Malcolm | last2=Moore | title=China snuffs out democracy protests | date=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12517909 | work=BBC News | title=China police break up 'protests' after online appeal | date=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iblKmk0zFyrloDdKUWP56cuOfD2Q?docId=CNG.7a0509e93accafbdfd4785aad6cc3018.5b1</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/20/us-china-protests-idUSTRE71J0TV20110220 | work=Reuters | title=Chinese police snuff out planned Arab-inspired protests | date=2011-02-20}}</ref>
  â   â
China also blocked coverage of the protests in the Arab world that continued after Mubarak's fall.<ref>http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-21/china-blocks-coverage-of-protests-to-squelch-egypt-style-revolt.html</ref>
  â   â
President [[Hu Jintao]] responded by calling top leaders into a "study session" to root out and tackle social issues before they "become threats to stability".<ref name="NYChina"/> In a speech at the [[Central Party School of the Communist Party of China|Central Party School]], Hu called out for tighter restrictions to the internet.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703498804576156203874160350.html?mod=googlenews_wsj|title=Call for Protests Unnerves China|author=Page, Jeremy|date=2011-02-20|accessdate=2011-02-20|work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> On February 18, an architect of the country's Internet monitoring software told a state newspaper that the program, already regarded as among the most stringent in the world, should be strengthened.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2011/02/20/2076764/china-cracks-down-on-protest-threats.html#ixzz1EYFczpfX |title=China cracks down on protest threats, rounds up dissidents|Publisher=Miami Herald Media|date=2011-02-20|accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
  â   â
Opposition leader there have supported [[China's Jasmine revolution]] for the democracy movements in the Middle East and Mainland China<ref>http://english.rti.org.tw/Content/GetSingleNews.aspx?ContentID=120031</ref>.
  â   â
===Iran===
  â
Supporters of the Green Movement gathered in scattered groups for the second time within a week to denounce the death of Saane Zhaleh, 26, and Mohammadi Mokhtari, 22, who were killed in Tehran on Monday. An opposition website affiliated to Mehdi Karroubi, a former presidential candidate, said that one person had been killed in Haft-e-Tir square in central Tehran when security forces opened fire at protesters. Dozens were arrested.
  â   â
===Algeria===
  â
Police thwarted a rally by thousands of pro-democracy supporters, breaking up the crowd into isolated groups to keep them from marching. Algerian opposition leader Tahar Besbes badly injured during pro-democracy rally when riot police clash with protesters. <ref>http://www.businessinsider.com/seeds-of-revolution-spread-in-middle-east-and-china-tweet-digest-and-expert-roundtables-2011-2</ref>
  â   â
===Yemen===
  â
The leader of Yemen's secessionist Southern Movement, Hasan Baoum, was arrested by an "armed military group" in an Aden hospital, according to his son, and shots were fired at a demonstration in the capital Sana'a, as unrest continued for a ninth consecutive day.
  â
===Morocco===
  â
Thousands took to the streets of Rabat, Casablanca, Tangier and Marrakech in peaceful protests demanding a new constitution, a change in government and an end to corruption. During a march on Hassan II Avenue in the capital, Rabat, demonstrators demanded a new constitution to bring more democracy to the country. They shouted slogans calling for economic opportunity, education reform, better health services, and help in coping with the rising cost of living.
  â   â
The Associated Press estimated the turnout in Rabat at 4,000. Organizers put the crowd outside Parliament at 20,000.<ref>http://www.boston.com/news/world/africa/articles/2011/02/21/moroccans_join_in_spreading_unrest</ref> The people were calling for a reduction in King Mohammed VIâs powers, better health services and reduced living costs.<ref>http://www.metro.co.uk/news/856068-protests-spread-to-streets-of-morocco</ref><ref>http://www.euronews.net/2011/02/20/moroccans-want-to-reign-in-royal-powers/</ref>
  â   â
===Libya===
  â   â
The Jasime Revolution also erupted in the country of Libya where enraged dissidents and the government are currently embroiled in titanic violence which has led to the freezing of the assets of Libyaâs leaders including Qaddafi and the withdrawal of oil companies from the country.
  â
Angry Demonstrators Call for Libya's Gadaffi to Step Down.<ref>http://news.yahoo.com/s/ac/20110216/pl_ac/7872960_angry_demonstrators_call_for_libyas_gadaffi_to_step_down</ref>
  â
Libya's security forces may yet manage to put down the demonstrations, as they did with a smaller upsurge in 2006, although that is looking increasingly unlikely as the violence spreads and escalates. Eyewitnesses speak of how the Libyan people appear to have lost their fear - and this is a regime more brutal and absolute than the one that was toppled in Egypt earlier this month.<ref>http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23925145-libyan-uprising-risks-red-faces-in-whitehall.do</ref><ref>http://www.hindustantimes.com/Second-wave-of-sandstorm/Article1-665188.aspx</ref>
 
==Oman==
==Oman==
